Award.AwardTitle: Correlating Grain Boundary Character to Micro-Fracture in Transparent Ceramic Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Transparent spinel is an advanced ceramic material that has great potential for use as a highly damage-resistant window material. It is fabricated by pressing individual grains of ceramic powder together at elevated temperature until they fuse to form a solid with excellent optical transparency and extreme hardness. Unfortunately, forming windows of practical size at an affordable cost is a significant challenge. This award supports fundamental research focused on a new approach to understanding and controlling the characteristics of a ceramic material. In particular, the work will explore the way that atoms arrange themselves at the boundaries between the individual grains during and after processing, and how different arrangements affect the material's strength. Improvements in spinel processing will benefit aerospace and military applications by providing a cost-effective solution when damage-resistant windows are needed. Such windows will offer improved protection for soldiers, sailors, pilots, and astronauts. Two female graduate students will be trained to work with cutting-edge techniques and tools. Undergraduate students will be engaged through academic-year and summer research projects. Benefits to the local community will take place through outreach events aimed at K-8 students.

Techniques such as aberration-corrected electron microscopy are now revealing that grain boundaries and interfaces constitute distinct thermodynamic states of matter that have consistent three-dimensional structures at the atomic level. These structures, termed complexions, are defined by thermodynamic variables such as chemical potential, temperature, pressure, and crystallography of the abutting grains. Furthermore, there are strong indications that control of boundary complexions is a method by which bulk properties may be controlled. In order to accelerate the use of complexion engineering as a tool for improving material properties, this research project is focused on the creation and validation of interface complexion time-temperature-transformation diagrams. These diagrams will be used to relate complexion types to interface fracture behavior. Aberration-corrected electron microscopy and small-scale mechanical test techniques will be used to shed light on the character and behavior of individual pure and doped boundaries. The demonstration that it is feasible to create and utilize boundary transformation diagrams, and that controlling complexions can also control boundary fracture behavior, will provide the ceramics community with a new means of engineering bulk material behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transparent magnesium aluminate spinel is an advanced ceramic material that has great potential for use as a highly damage-resistant window material. It is fabricated by pressing individual grains of ceramic powder together at elevated temperature until they fuse to form a solid with excellent optical transparency and extreme hardness. Unfortunately, forming windows of practical size at an affordable cost is a significant challenge. This project comprises fundamental research focused on a new approach to understanding and controlling the characteristics of a ceramic material. In particular, the work has explored the way that atoms arrange themselves at the boundaries between the individual grains during and after processing, and how different arrangements affect the material's strength. Improvements in spinel processing benefit aerospace and military applications by providing a cost-effective solution when damage-resistant windows are needed. Such windows will offer improved protection for soldiers, sailors, pilots, and astronauts.

The first major discovery of the project is that a type of scientific diagram called a “complexion time-temperature-transformation (CTTT) diagram” can be created for spinel. It is based on a diagram that is routinely used by engineers for the selection of the processing time and temperature used to control the internal structure of many materials. This is the first time that such a diagram has been created for the boundaries of spinel. The diagram clearly indicates combinations of time and temperature that result in certain types of internal structure, each of which is expected to result in different properties. We validated this diagram by processing spinel in several different ways, showing that the diagram can accurately predict the internal structure that results.

The second major discovery of the project is that a boundary’s chemistry and structure can be directly related to its mechanical properties in a predictable way. We developed and used micro-mechanical testing techniques that make it possible to break tiny specimens that each contains only one boundary. Using these techniques, we showed that the addition of a small amount of Europium (a so-called Rare Earth Element) to the spinel can significantly change the structure but the behavior of individual boundaries is unchanged. This gives an engineer a way to alter structure without accidentally altering other properties at the same time.

Validation of the CTTT diagram approach, development of new micro-mechanical testing techniques, and demonstration of the usefulness of Europium as an additive to spinel are all important advances that can be used by others in the materials engineering field to advance the development of affordable spinel windows.

Two female Ph.D. students performed the majority of the work. One has graduated and has taken a teaching position at a university and the other is about to graduate. Both have given a number of professional presentations describing their results, and together they have produced two published papers with two more that are anticipated.

There have been several outreach activities intended to reach members of the local community and the undergraduate population at Lehigh University. The primary purpose of these outreach events is enhancing public understanding and increasing interest in learning and careers in science and engineering. For example, the PI and graduate students participated in Lehigh's Summer Engineering Institute (SEI) for three years. The SEI is a four-week summer residential program of intensive classroom study and research for exceptionally talented, rising high school juniors and seniors. It engaged 50 high school students from diverse backgrounds in a series of stimulating engineering activities. Together with a colleague in the Lehigh University Design program, the PI created a multi-day laboratory experience that involved additive manufacturing, mechanical testing, computer aided design, and finite element analysis in the context of a hypothetical NASA manned Mars mission.

For several years the PI has also engaged incoming first-year Lehigh undergraduates in two extracurricular events focused on materials engineering. The first was a half-day hands-on activity for the Lehigh Women Engineers "PreLUsion" orientation event. The young women involved in the activity participated in a miniature version of a mechanical testing and design activity that is part of the normal sophomore core labs in the Materials major. The objective was to provide them with a sense of what they would be doing once they made it past the introductory courses typical of the first year in the engineering program. The second was a 1-hour lecture and discussion that engaged over 100 incoming students in the exploration of materials as significant enablers of technological progress. Examples were given of materials developments over thousands of years and the engineering progress that resulted. The students were then asked to identify and discuss a materials advance that they would welcome as a way of enhancing the performance or value of a product known to them. These introductory undergraduate programs were designed to attract and retain students in engineering, particularly young women.
